Title: Masters in Data Science | Sports Data Scientist
Summary: With a keen interest in statistics from a young age, I have completed my undergraduate B.Sc. degree in Economics, Mathematics and Statistics, securing the first rank. I also pursued my Master's in Data Science in Liverpool, UK as a recipient of the British Council India 70th Anniversary Scholarship. I graduated with an overall distinction, including a distinction for my Master's dissertation.   My primary interest has always remained in sports, and the vast applications of data analytics in this field continued to become apparent during the course of my studies. This inspired me to focus my Master's thesis on the development of a live sports analysis model, using semantic analysis of web-casting text commentary for live detection of events and momentum shifts.  While pursuing my degrees, I have also completed internships and part-time jobs, including data collection, data analysis, content writing, SEO, and volunteer work. I also completed a consultancy in Data Science which involved development of an interactive dashboard using Shiny and R. I also worked extensively with internet sourcing of information and data, including with regards to fundraising at Liverpool Hope.   I aim to combine the skills I have honed to provide novel insights into data, particularly in sports, and present this in a way that is accessible and comprehensible to all.

Using  color  and  motion  properties  of  fire,  the  boundary  of  the  moving  region  in  the  color segmented  image  is  determined  and  based  on  amount  of  fire  pixels  in  this  area,  fire  detection  is  decided. Title: Jr. Data Scientist at The World Bank
Organization Description 2: Co-authored working paper, "Can Africa be a manufacturing destination? Labor costs in comparative perspective". I assessed the labor costs of African manufacturing firms in comparison with firms in other developing countries to estimate the potential for Africa to industrialize. I constructed a panel data set from 39 individual economies datasets of the World Bank Enterprise survey data, involving intensive data cleaning and preparation. The analysis included building fixed- and random-effects multivariate regression models and Levihnson-Petrin/Oley-Pakes production functions with the use of Stata to assess the relationship between labor costs and firm productivity. I presented the paper at a conference organized by the Institute of Labor Economics at the African Development Bank in November 2017. The work has featured in The Economist, Quartz Africa, and several regional/African media outlets.  Founded a data visualization venture, called "Chart of the week" series, consisting of a series of blogs, focused on data visualization to present latest development economics research in an effective manner. I used the most efficient tool among R shiny, JavaScript, Tableau, and tools supported by D3.js to produce a unique set of weekly interactive visualizations for the blog series. Within its first month, our work has been featured on Business Standard, LiveMint, and others.  I supported analysis for Economic Survey of India 2018, led by Arvind Subramanian (Chief Economic Advisor, India. I built a country-level dataset comprising of 50+ income indicators; the process involved data processing and data cleaning. I analyzed the possibility of a "middle-income trap" for India with data visualization of the sector-wise growth of India and China. see less
Organization Description 3: Built a tax metrics data portal of 200+ economies and 35+ years for public consumption. I single-handedly led the construction of a country-level panel database of 750+ tax-related metrics. Title: Former U.S. Chief Data Scientist
Summary: DJ Patil has held a variety of roles in Academia, Industry, and Government.   He is Head of Technology for Devoted Health, a Senior Fellow at the Belfer Center at the Harvard Kennedy School, and an Advisor to Venrock Partners.  Dr. Patil was appointed by President Obama to be the first U.S. Chief Data Scientist where his efforts led to the establishment of nearly 40 Chief Data Officer roles across the Federal government. He also established new health care programs including the Precision Medicine Initiative and the Cancer Moonshot, new criminal justice reforms including the Data-Driven Justice and Police Data Initiatives that cover more than 94 million Americans, as well as leading the national data efforts. He also has been active in national security and for his efforts was awarded by Secretary Carter the Department of Defense Medal for Distinguished Public Service which the highest honor the department bestows on a civilian.   In industry, he led the product teams at RelateIQ which was acquired by Salesforce, was founding board member for Crisis Text Line which works to use new technologies to provide on demand mental and crisis support, and was a member of the venture firm Greylock Partners. He has also was Chief Scientist, Chief Security Officer and Head of Analytics and Data Product Teams at the LinkedIn Corporation where he co-coined the term Data Scientist. He has also held a number of roles at Skype, PayPal, and eBay.    As a member of the faculty at the University of Maryland, his research focused on nonlinear dynamics and chaos theory and he helped start a major research initiative on numerical weather prediction.  As an AAAS Science & Technology Policy Fellow for the Department of Defense, Dr. Patil directed new efforts to leverage social network analysis and the melding of computational and social sciences to anticipate emerging threats to the US. He has also co-chaired a major review of US efforts to prevent bioweapons proliferation in Central Asia and co-founded the Iraqi Virtual Science Library (IVSL).  In 2104 he was selected by the World Economic Forum as a Young Global Leader and is also a Member of the Council of Foreign Relations.  More details can be found on his LinkedIn profile: http://www.linkedin.com/in/dpatil and can be followed on twitter @dpatil
Organization Description 1: We're on a mission to build a health plan that takes care of *every* member like they were a member of our family. We do that through great technology, data, design, and most of all love. Check us out at Devoted.com

Right out of college, with a Bachelor's degree in IT, I knew I wanted to continue working with technology but not in the web tech/software engineering domain. I started with product analytics and management at a software company. One of my key achievements here was using data driven decisions to make business recommendations towards the redesign of my product. These recommendations helped the company in increasing the user base for the product. This solely happened because I am someone who has the skills to deep-dive into the product not only from the corporate business side but also from the customer perspective. I am adept in identifying pain points from a user point of view. This is precisely when I realised I can leverage data, which is present in any and all industries, tap into insights that weren't explored before and benefit not only the company, but the consumer as well. A couple of experiences later, I am now a proud Master's graduate from the University of Maryland - go Terps! - looking to leverage my skills in an industry and company that is not only focused on their corporate standing but also the social good of the community. That is who I want to work for.  I am also dedicated to continued learning/education. With the evolution of technology, it is vital to stay at the forefront of that advancement. As a by-product of this belief, I hold an online nano-degree in Predictive Business Analytics.  Apart from my academics and career, I like to read (crime, mystery - Agatha Christie is my #1) and travel (I'm fortunate enough to have visited over 10 countries). Title: Sr. Data Scientist at Stanford | Top Voice 2019: Data Science & Analytics
Summary: I have more than seven years of progressive data science and machine learning expertise, having spearheaded myriad data analyses from the ground up across numerous organizations, most notably spanning the following industries: law, financial technology, insurance technology, and education.  The common theme across my direct work with attorneys, CFO, CRO, CTO and CDO has been deriving highly impactful and results-oriented actionable business insights from data, as a senior data scientist.   For example, I helped numerous lawyers at Ogletree Deakins in estimating total liability exposure for clients associated with several multi-million-dollar, class-action lawsuits. In those 4 years, I also invented proprietary Monte Carlo simulation to predict the settlement value of multi-millions class action lawsuit - a first in the legal profession. The work led to a Data Driven Award in 2018: https://www.law360.com/articles/1105806/data-driven-lawyer-ogletree-s-evan-moses   Recently, I worked alongside LoanHero's Chief Risk Officer, developing credit and risk models that were responsible for LoanHero‚Äôs risk and fraud management, accounting for over $100 million in collective transactions. As a first data scientist on Robo-Advisor team at Credit Sesame working directly with CTO, I spearheaded multiple data science initiatives and built a team there. Additionally, I have co-authored a Whitepaper that investigated the actual cost savings for a client using CLARA Provider‚Äôs outcome-based approach as a provider selection tool for workers compensation claims at CLARA Analytics within the first three months. Finally, I'm currently applying data science to improve various processes in multiple departments in Stanford University.   I hold a B.S. in Mathematics and Accounting from UCLA, and a M.S. in Engineering Management from USC. I continue updating my skills and have also earned several certifications including but not limited to: Project Management Professional (PMP), Six Sigma Green Belt, Data Incubator Data Science Bootcamp, Stanford Machine Learning, and Stanford ICME Fundamentals of Data Science.  In my free time, I love discussing data science with friends. I would really like to introduce my proposed data science minimum curriculum to aspiring data scientists below.

Title: Data Scientist at CiBO Technologies
Organization Description 2: I was a Research Associate at Harvard University in the Department of Organismic and Evolutionary Biology. I am modeling plant phenology (seasonal changes) from local to continental scales by bringing together data from multiple sources, including data from national databases, citizen science, remote earth-based cameras, and satellite sensors. I am also flying unmanned aerial vehicles ("drones") at the Arnold Arboretum to image thousands of trees from above in order to track their seasonal progression and connect these seasonal changes to temperature and local topographic variation. The ultimate goal of both projects is to better understand how climate change affects plants across the United States, with implications for agriculture, forestry, public health, and conservation. see less
Organization Description 3: As a Postdoctoral Fellow at Harvard University in the lab of Dr. Andrew Richardson, I designed and built Season Spotter (seasonspotter.org), an online citizen science project that asked volunteers to annotate images of plants from remote automated cameras. The resulting data is contributing to a continental-scale understanding of the seasonal dynamics of terrestrial plants, in support of climate change and carbon cycling research. see less
Organization Description 5: As a graduate student in the department of Ecology, Evolution, and Behavior, I worked on multiple projects that investigated the impact of human actions on natural systems. These included:  1. Developing a model that elucidated the dynamics of the disease bovine tuberculosis in lions in Kruger National Park, South Africa, in support of park conservation and management decisions.  2. Designing and running the highly successful citizen science project Snapshot Serengeti (snapshotserengeti.org, in collaboration with others), which asks volunteers to identify African animals in images taken by automated cameras in the Serengeti, Tanzania. The resulting data are being used to understand spatial and temporal dynamics of African animals, as well as for developing machine learning approaches in computer vision.  3. Developing advanced statistical models to tease apart the effects of major disturbance (e.g. clear-cutting) on the long-term trajectories of ecosystems.  4. Conducting an experiment to investigate the impact of local plant diversity on soybean crop production through the enhancement of insect biological control of soybean aphids.  5. Conducting an experiment to understand the impacts of climate warming on grassland insect and spider communities.  6. Analyzing long-term data from a decades-long experiment designed to understand the fundamental dynamics of plant competition and dispersal in a temperate grassland.  7. Quantitatively assessing the environmental impacts of U.S. beef production. see less
Organization Description 6: Designed and developed a computer model to test hypotheses on the evolution of social behavior in lions.
Organization Description 7: Research alternative scenarios for raising beef in the U.S., taking into account both economic and environmental considerations.
Organization Description 8: Processed incoming donations to organization and outgoing correspondence to donors. Improved and streamlined internal business practices.

Title: Data Scientist I at GumGum
Summary: I work as a NLP Data Scientist at GumGum where I tackle interesting NLP problems in the Digital Ads space. I graduated with Masters in Computer Science from Arizona State University with my thesis in the area of Natural Language Processing.  To pursue my interest in the Data Science and Analytics field, I have been focused in research in the area of Natural Language Processing. My Thesis is about improving Textual Entailment which is an important precursor to all Natural Language Question Answering systems. Other areas of my research work include Clinical Natural Language Processing(NLP) which involves applying the techniques of NLP on the Electronic Health Records to automate and aid various Health Care Domain participants.   I also worked part-time as a Data Analyst at Enterprise Marketing Hub in ASU tackling marketing use cases for ASU involving Text Analytics, Topic Modeling and building Dashboards, aiding the decision makers at ASU.  As an Associate Data Analyst in Sapient's Data Engineering and Analytics Capabilities team, I worked on building Predictive Models for Capital Market use cases at Sapient using Machine Learning algorithms and researched data-driven ideas for areas like Customer Segmentation, Hyper parameter optimization in Predictive Models, ensemble methods for supervised learning algorithms, Log Analytics, Inferential statistical analysis and developed interpretable models. Majorly worked on Python, R, Tableau and MySQL.   I joined Arizona State University in Fall'17 and graduated in August 2019 with my Thesis in the area of Natural Language Inference. Summary: I'm a novice data enthusiast, who'd love to eventually become a storyteller of data. I find working on understanding data with people towards a common, worthwhile goal, hugely enjoyable and rewarding. Throughout my work and internship experience, I was extremely pleased that as a team, we successfully implemented systems so as to solve challenging problems affecting living beings. No matter where I work, I hope to achieve a comparable team goal by working together on the challenging task of building machine learning and data visualisation models to the point of making data-driven, actionable decisions, thereby accelerating growth and client satisfaction.
Organization Description 2: I worked as a Data Scientist at Calpine Labs, Ernakulam, which is the R&D wing of Calpine Group, a company focusing on developing software for the healthcare and HR analytics domain, where I have had the opportunity to work on the HRTray project, which involves text mining & information retrieval in the social media domain, while simultaneously improving my research and engineering skills.  I was responsible for the design and implementation of an Identity Resolution engine that aims to:  1. Perform identity searching for finding other potential social profiles associated with a person, given some verified info about the person (such as name, email, location, work, etc.). 2. Perform identity linking so as to score the potential social profiles of the person, with the highest scored profiles being most likely to be associated with the person.  This consisted of research and development work involving the use of clustering and string matching techniques, in order to build a profile scoring engine using text and image based similarity measures. The work also involved fetching data from API sources and scraping publicly available social profile data from multiple platforms. see less
Organization Description 3: I worked as an intern at Phenom People, where my role mostly involved transforming and analysing job-domain data. Specifically, I performed the following tasks:  1. Download data through forums/APIs/XML feeds using requests and BeautifulSoup modules in Python. 2. Parse downloaded data using json and xml modules in Python. 3. Insert the parsed data into CSV/TSV files using csv and pandas modules in Python. 4. Do n-gram based frequency analysis, correlation analysis, and aggregation-based analysis on text data. 5. Do POS-tagging on data and extract fields from it using POS-tag-based regular expression matches, using the pattern module in Python. 6. Use MongoDB to store large amounts of data which have no fixed schema. 7. Use bash scripting and Linux command line tools such as awk, sed and grep for fast data preprocessing and to automate data insertion/downloading. 8. Use crontab to schedule scripts periodically. see less
Organization Title 4: National Network for Mathematical and Computational Biology (NNMCB) Intern
Organization Description 4: As an NNMCB intern, I performed a study of graph centrality indices, and identified crucial habitat patches of tigers in ecological networks, using graph theoretic modelling and centrality analysis of tiger habitat patches. This included:  1. Creating a graph model from the adjacency matrix of the habitat data. 2. Study and evaluation of various graph centrality measures. 3. Computing correlation between the centrality measures. 4. Deriving meaningful interpretations from the model.  In particular, 23 habitat patches were analysed and ranked using various centrality indices, helping in focusing conservation efforts for those patches. The work resulted in two publications. see less

Title: Chief Data Scientist at FOXO BioScience
Summary: I'm not very active on LinkedIn. You can contact me at http://randalolson.com/contact  I'm the Chief Data Scientist at FOXO BioScience, where I'm building a data science team that is merging cutting edge epigenetics research with advanced machine learning methods to improve life expectancy prediction for the life insurance industry and beyond. I specialize in AI, machine learning, and data visualization, although I‚Äôm always learning something new to make myself more useful to my clients and collaborators. I regularly write about my latest work on my personal blog, where I've become known for computing optimal road trips around the world and solving Where‚Äôs Waldo?, among many other creative applications of machine learning. My work has been featured all over the world and in the news, including the New York Times, Wired, FiveThirtyEight, and much more.  I work tirelessly to promote open and reproducible science, leading by example and openly publishing my work on GitHub and open access journals. I'm also passionate about training the next generation of data scientists to be more efficient, effective, and collaborative in their work, and do so by writing online tutorials, teaching hands-on workshops, and mentoring local students in my research specialties. If you would like to commission me to teach a workshop or give a talk in your area, please get in touch.  You can follow me on Twitter (https://twitter.com/randal_olson) or Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/RandalSOlson), where I post new data visualizations every day. (The data visualizations aren‚Äôt always created by me.) I'm also a community leader for the popular data visualization subreddit reddit.com/r/DataIsBeautiful, which now serves over 2 million unique readers every month.  Please take a look at my web site and blog below to see of what I've been working on lately.

I love sharing my findings at all forums from peer-reviewed articles to public lectures and in magazines for the general public. I am passionate to use my knowledge in climate change and data science to assess climate risks and manage the disaster.

Learning Pyhton, Panda, SQL, Mongo-DB, R, Web scraping, machine learning, and visualization of data using Leaflet, plotly, GeoJson. see less
Organization Title 3: Teaching Environmental science  and Analytical Chemistry
Organization Description 3: Teaching chemistry is fun as chemistry is an essential component of our life . One can observe redox chemistry taking place within ourselves- uptake of oxygen and release of carbon dioxide by heamoglobins; catalytic chemistry, rusting of iron and other metals in areas closer to beach due to chlorine chemistry, splitting of water to oxygen by plants. Even frizzy water in your hand is produced after solving PV=nRT. Chemistry is everywhere in offices, homes, schools, hospitals, industry and even at the beach while enjoying sunshine after applying sun screen or tanning lotion. see less
Organization Description 4: I conduct research on the long range transport of pollutants which includes heterogeneous chemical reactions in the troposphere. I basically use oxygen isotopes as a finger prints to identify different chemical reaction pathways.
Organization Description 5: Photochemical reactions leading to the exchange of oxygen isotopes between ozone and carbon dioxide. This reaction is important in the stratosphere where excess 17O can be used as probe to study the ozone cycle and age of the air. The acquisition of oxygen isotope anomaly (or heavy isotopes) in CO2 over million years leads to detectable change in oxygen isotope composition. As anomaly is produced in the stratosphere and removed in the troposphere by the plants, the oxygen isotope record in ice cores is used to estimate plant productivity over 60, 000 yr. see less

Title: Data Science Executive, Mathematician, Investor
Summary: Data science pioneer, founder, author, patent owner, CEO, investor, with broad spectrum of domain expertise, technical knowledge, and proven success in bringing measurable added value to companies ranging from startups to fortune 100, across multiple industries (finance, Internet, media, IT, security) and domains (data science, operations research, machine learning, AI, computer science, business intelligence, IoT).  Vincent developed and deployed new techniques such as hidden decision trees (for scoring and fraud detection), automated tagging, indexing and clustering of large document repositories, black-box, scalable, simple, noise-resistant regression known as the Jackknife Regression (fit for real-time or automated data processing), model-free confidence intervals, combinatorial feature selection algorithms, detecting causation not correlations, and generally speaking, the invention of a set of consistent robust statistical / machine learning techniques that can be understood, implemented, interpreted, leveraged and fine-tuned by the non-expert. Vincent also invented many synthetic metrics that work better than old-fashioned stats, especially on badly-behaved sparse big data. Some of these techniques have been implemented in a Map-Reduce Hadoop-like environment. Some are concerned with identifying true signal in an ocean of noisy data.  Vincent is a former post-doctorate of Cambridge University and the National Institute of Statistical Sciences.  He created the first IoT platform to automate growth and content generation for digital publishers, using a system of API's for machine-to-machine communications, involving Hootsuite, Twitter, and Google Analytics. Title: Decision Scientist | Toastmasters | Data & Insights
Summary: Growing up between Cairo, Dubai, Bangalore and Mumbai - I've always been quick to adapt to new situations and have  found it easy to work with people and make new friends. My favourite subject from the time I was in school has been Mathematics, as even the most complex problems always seem to have a solution.  Being a decision scientist, helped me find the perfect balance between my passion for math and my love for storytelling.   I now get to read and analyze data and then translate them into meaningful insights for my clients.  Introducing analytics into spaces that still leverage SME‚Äôs over a data driven approach to make major business decisions is a key goal of mine.
Organization 1: Krenicki Center for Business Analytics & Machine Learning
Organization Description 2: A Dynamic Ticket Pricing Solution for¬†the NFL Team  Our study explored two solutions to optimize revenue with dynamic pricing for the Indianapolis Colts. While one approach focusses on revenue maximization, the other explores bridging the revenue gap between the primary and secondary markets and suggesting primary prices based on historical secondary market data.  On implementing solution two on the primary data for 2019, we realized a potential revenue increase of¬† 10% ($125,000) by setting solution two's suggested price.¬†  Our next steps would be an extension to the project, by adding consideration of customers buying patterns and other characteristics that might enhance the reliability of the revenue optimization¬†model. see less
Organization Description 3: Measuring Promotional Effectiveness in Home D√©cor and their impact on customer loyalty  Kirkland's initiated the project to improve its promotions and customer loyalty programs. We helped the company develop and validate models that helped them quantify the incremental impact of change in discounts. Our case study provides a novel way to not only see the impact but also allows our client to see the potential increase in sales revenue by increasing/decreasing discount %.  We were able to show how using these insights for future promotions can help drive strategic improvements to loyal-type customers while not losing unnecessary margin to those groups that are more price-driven or would have purchased the product anyway had a sale not been run. see less
Organization Description 4: Worked on designing and developing a Power BI decision board that captures the health of business for the Aftersales division of a Fortune 10 automotive company. Various teams within the company use this decision board everyday as a single source of truth to engage in conversations and take collective decisions, enabling them to identify opportunities, leading to increase in cash flow to achieve sales targets.  Having completed the descriptive portion of the dashboard, we worked on incorporating prescriptive measures such as dynamically identifying sales opportunity, and then creating a test and control scenario which will help in estimating impact of the recommendations  Previously, worked on projects to increase the warranty recovery for the company. Over a six-month period, my team and I successfully demonstrated the value of data driven decision making. (Using time series forecasting, survival analysis, classification techniques, text analytics & dashboarding)  - Predictive model - used machine learning algorithms and time-to-event analysis, to classify suppliers based on their tendencies to pay based on features of a bill, to prioritize monthly recovery pipeline.  - Forecasting model - gave point forecast of Settlement Amounts from suppliers in the next 12 months in order to provide clarity on the cash inflow from suppliers and for better target setting.  - Text Analytics - was implemented to analyze supplier contracts and to segregate them into their buckets, in order to reduce settlement disputes  - Dashboarding - The predictive and forecasting models were encapsulated in an RShiny dashboard, which generated the input files for a Power BI dashboard. The dashboard was used by the clients to drive key decisions regarding - target setting, recovery pipeline management, and billing resolution see less
Organization Description 5: In the Hindustan Coca Cola Beverages - Bidadi plant, it was observed, that the conveyors were driven by motors running at the same speed, irrespective of the pack size and the rate of production (bottles/minute). This resulted in large wastage of energy as conveyors could save energy, by varying their run time and run speed depending on the production.  Automating certain functions in manufacturing and material handling operations, improves productivity and efficiency, creating cost savings. However, a growing area of concern is increasing energy costs. This project, dealt with the calculation and development of a solution, to reduce the energy consumption of the PET 600 line during production.  A solution was developed, by careful observation and calculation of the speeds of the various motors and drives installed on the line, and the frequency of the motors was varied in accordance to the running pack size and a noticeable amount of energy was saved. see less

Title: Data Scientist and Researcher at Indian Institute of Science
Summary: My areas of interests are Machine Learning, Deep Learning, Human-Computer Interaction, and Numerical Linear Algebra.  My research lies at the intersection of these areas to create physical and virtual interventions that impact lives on a wider scale.  I have been working in the aforementioned areas (both corporate and academia) for 6 years now and even though I have written them separately, I strongly believe in their entanglement. I see research as a practice to ask the right questions when solving a desired problem. I have done some theoretical works like finding error estimators for iterative algorithms (linear algebra), research on gradient based algorithms (deep learning) and have also built intelligent user interfaces for people who are physically challenged (human-computer interaction), machine learning solutions for manufacturing enterprises for detecting defects and root cause analysis (data science).  My recent work is an adaptive virtual keyboard for people with severe speech and motor impairment that can be used using eyes rather than hand held devices like mouse etc. The keyboard is integrated with a customized machine learning algorithm for dynamic adaptation of dwell time (minimum time to click through gaze) by learning user interaction with the interface. Meanwhile, I am also building an indigenous eye tracker for fighter jet pilots using Computer Vision. Please find detailed description of my projects through my website below.
Organization Description 1: I am working in the Interaction Design Lab at CPDM, IISc. I am building softwares for children with severe speech and motor impairment (SSMI). I use Deep Learning and Computer Vision to make the applications intelligent which come under the category of Intelligent user interfaces. The current application is a software which helps SSMI users to use computers with eye gaze replacing the need for handheld cursor movements from input devices like mouse or joystick.  On the hardware side, I am making proof of concepts for creating tangible interactions in Virtual Reality. The current prototype I am building is a Haptic glove to increase users immersion in virtual environments. see less
Organization Description 2: Deep Learning : Optimization : Linear algebra

I have worked for the Project DMI (Digital Manufacturing Insights) which was first cloud based product from Labs. I worked on the Root Cause Analysis - to evaluate both quantitative and qualitative reasons for defects encountered in a manufacturing setting using Machine Learning.  Second project was in the domain of Predictive Quality Manufacturing (PQM). It involved building customized machine learning algorithms to automate the process of quality prediction of manufacturing products using time series data for manufacturing enterprises. see less

Summary: Curious and innovative individual, with an aptitude for problem-solving and attention to detail. I have been working in the domain of Microwave Remote Sensing, particularly in the application of Deep Learning to Synthetic Aperture Radar data.  My research has developed a set of novel methodologies that incorporate physical radar scattering principles into a novel deep neural network architecture for the analysis of remote sensing images. Applications of the technology developed include - classiÔ¨Åcation of challenging urban areas in radar images, urban change detection using minimal training/ supervision and the combination of multi-frequency radar data for agricultural crop classiÔ¨Åcation. Organization Description 3: The thesis develops a set of novel methodologies that incorporate physical scattering principles into a Deep Neural Network architecture for the analysis of remote sensing images. The major research contributions are summarized as follows:  - ClassiÔ¨Åcation of Urban Areas in Polarimetric Synthetic Aperture Radar Images: The objective of this study was to be able to identify urban, non-urban and water land cover classes. A simulated urban target was generated to create synthetic urban scattering data, which was used to augment the training data. This improved the generalization ability of the network, improving performance over contemporary techniques.  -Urban Change Detection Using a Semi-supervised Deep Learning Technique: Often in case of a disaster like Ô¨Çoods, a quick characterization of damage to urban areas is required. However, not much ground truth information is available making it diÔ¨Écult to train machine learning models. In this work, an associative manifold growing technique was used to bolster the training minimal information available, and improve change detection performance.  -Combination of Multi-Frequency Radar Data for Crop ClassiÔ¨Åcation: A novel tensorization approach was used to combine a multi-frequency dataset. Each frequency is sensitive to diÔ¨Äerent biophysical parameters of the agricultural crop. Thus, in combination, they are able to improve the ability of the algorithm to identify that crop. see less

Title: Head of Data Science Evangelism and Marketing at Coiled.  Data scientist, writer, educator, machine learner, occasional podcaster, consultant.
Summary: I'm a data scientist, writer, educator & podcaster. My interests include promoting data & AI literacy/fluency, helping to spread data skills through organizations and society and doing amateur stand up comedy in NYC. I do many of these at DataCamp, a data science training company educating over 3 million learners worldwide through interactive courses on the use of Python, R, SQL, Git, Bash and Spreadsheets in a data science context. I have spearheaded the development of over 25 courses in DataCamp‚Äôs Python curriculum, impacting over 170,000 learners worldwide through my own courses. I host and produce the data science podcast DataFramed, in which I use long-format interviews with working data scientists to delve into what actually happens in the space and what impact it can and does have. I earned my PhD in Mathematics from the University of New South Wales, Australia and have conducted biomedical research at the Max Planck Institute in Germany and Yale University, New Haven. For more information, check out my website here: http://hugobowne.github.io/

Title: Principal Data Scientist at WalmartLabs
Summary: My research interests lie broadly in statistical methodology and machine learning algorithms as well as applied statistics in various domains. The central goal is to enable reasoning under uncertainty, to understand natural and statistical phenomena, and to meet challenges from modern data (including dimensionality, scalability, structural complexity and varying data quality etc). Of particular interest are the following topics:      - High dimensional statistical inference     - Statistics and machine learning for big data     - Methodology related to data heterogeneity     - Clustering and classification     - Data contamination and domain adaptation     - Human learning inspired learning algorithms (e.g., co-training, active learning)     - Ensemble methods for statistical learning and inference     - Spatial and computational statistics     - Imaging and computer vision.  Feel free to visit my web:          https://sites.google.com/site/dhyan2004/

Cherre's Knowledge Graph contains public record information on property taxes on almost every county in the US. This involves putting together millions of records all with different formats. My job is to train algorithms that can detect all the records belonging to the same actor (person, company, government) in an automated and timely fashion.

Title: Data Scientist
Summary: The one thing in common among my work experiences has been the ability to understand the business needs of the company and the technical challenges of the problem at hand to develop a practical solution that works well and gets to market in a timely fashion.  In addition to this I build strong relationships with the people that work for me and with me. As a result I have a network of some of the best technical people in New England to draw from whenever I start a new job.  Currently, I have used my network to help start up my own company, called Fast Strike Sports, that makes fantasy sports games for state lotteries.  Previously, I was the VP of Science at matchmine where I helped refine an existing recommendation system to make it flexible enough to meet the needs of a wide range of partners (movies, music, videos, blogs and podcasts). This was not a collaborative filtering approach but one that focused on understanding the content of the items and the interests of the users. It required gathering data from many sources, analyzing it, and understanding user behaviors.  The work at matchmine was similar in many ways to work I did at Predictive Networks/Predictive Media. I was with Predictive from beginning to end and helped design an ad targeting system that had 2 million users at its peak, delivered over a billion ads, and had zero down time and zero complaints and in controlled studies was shown to deliver CTR 4-5 times higher than the industry average. Also at Predictive I helped develop a recommendation system for TV and movie viewing that was used to integrate VOD offerings into a unified experience for users. The IP from that venture is currently owned by a holding company for Comcast.  I am looking forward to my next opportunity to lead a technical team tasked with solving interesting problems.  Specialties: algorithm development, recommendations systems, targeted advertising
Organization Description 4: Data Scientist working on the Big Data team using Hadoop to analyze data across several different sources of data. Used the data to generate cross sell leads for Constant Contact's event product and coupon product. Analyzed emails to create the best time to send algorithm based on when subscribers are most likely to open their emails and analyzed subject lines to generate the keywords that produce the best open rates. Created a subscriber engagement metric to allow customers to easily identify which contacts were most engaged. see less
Organization Description 5: Fast Strike Games develops interactive games for state lotteries including numbers games and fantasy sports. Our proprietary research allows us to design games that are legal state lottery games, fast and easy to play and offer large prizes ($250k and up). Our games appeal to a younger demographic group than normal state lottery games and leverage social networking to allow users to not only play the lottery game but play each other head-to-head. Our technology allows us to design games for any sport that has a reasonable amount of statistical categories. see less

Managed an R+D team of 10 people that developed tools to allow us to program individual stores for the 20,000 different country and device combinations in a scalable way and algorithms to keep sort orders relevant and to make personalized recommendations. Our tools and improvements to search resulted in the store growing from 1 million downloads a day to 10 million downloads a day in 18 months. see less

Organization Description 5: Electrocoalescence and Film thinning  Coalescence plays an important role in the rain cycle, various separation processes and food products. Electro coalescence is applying electric potential to make oil water separation process more effective. A lot of research is being done in this field and to set up an appropriate apparatus. Coalescence depends upon the stability and drainage of thin film just before they coalesce thus it is very important to study stability of thin film. The purpose of this project is to study coalescence, various apparatus proposed to study the thin film and to make a modified and simple apparatus. As this thin film drains thickness of the thin film changes and this is observed by using Newton‚Äôs ring apparatus.  ‚Ä¢ Studied effect of varying electric field on coalescence of various fluids ‚Ä¢ Studied on film thinning phenomenon occurrence while foaming,emulsion and suspension, effects of various surfactants on the same. ‚Ä¢ Exploring various existing setups used for studying coalescence ‚Ä¢ Designed a prototype of an apparatus to observe Newton's ring due to coalescence

Summary: Wei has a Ph.D. in economics from the University of California, Santa Cruz. Organization Description 2: Measuring Credit Insurance Impacts on Online Lending Market - Analyzed a dataset of detailed info on over 300k listings and 2M bids from an online platform - Quantified causal impacts of credit insurance on market demand, supply, and investors' behavior using a Diff-in-Diff model with a quasi-experiment feature - Estimated credit insurance impact on funding rate for individual loans with Doubly Robust estimator  Analysis of Online Lenders' Efficiency - Developed a theoretical model delivering testable empirical inference on efficiency of online credit lenders - Explored exogenous variation in competition with a Heckman correction model to address sample selection issue in the comparison of impacts on ex ante funding likelihood and ex post default risk for different borrower traits - Estimated gender impacts on funding probability for borrowers and lenders respectively by exploiting randomness in loan posting time  Fiscal Multiplier Asymmetry over Business Cycles - Measured changes in aggregate output, consumption, investment, and employment as responses to exogenous tax policy changes identified by narrative analysis - Impulse responses were estimated by a State-Dependent model using Local Projections and Vector Autoregression, that distinguishes the responses in economic booms vs. in recessions  Leverage and Debt Overhang - Identified stylized facts that leverage moved in the opposite directions for the financial and nonfinancial sectors during and after the 08-09 crisis using aggregate- and micro-level data - Built and solved a dynamic stochastic general equilibrium model where the production sector is constrained by debt overhang to explain the empirical leverage movements and economic volatilities  Realized Estimators of Asset Return Volatilities - Title: Data Scientist
Organization Description 1: BBE(Bad Buyer Experience) project
Organization Description 2: Assortment Optimization
Education Description 1: My research project focuses on models for population dynamics of predator-prey interactions. They are of reaction-diffusion type. To be specific, my models are nonlocal in terms of the competition among the prey. The major analytical theory is based on linear stability analysis. By performing linear stability analyses of the critical points, I can determine their stability. My focus is the coexistence critical point since it involves both predators and prey and complex phenomena of interactions. Based on the analysis of the coexistence point, I can find the stability boundaries which separate regions of stability from regions of instability. I explore how the boundaries change with the increase in nonlocality. For the numerical part, I use spectral methods to implement the simulations over periodic domains in Fortran. The simulations determine patterns near the stability boundaries and also nonlinear patterns far from the stability boundaries.

Title: Research Scientist at Wright State Research Institute
Summary: If there is one thing that drives the many varied aspects of my career, it is the desire to build large systems with a large number of users that have a big impact. This has led me to focus on distributed computing and networking, machine learning, natural language processing, security and more. Though these skills don't necessarily lend themselves to a single domain of effort, it has given me a number of perspectives that inform my designs of complex systems. Largely, I am therefore an architect and programmer whose focus is a balance between human and machine intelligence.   These perspectives are also taken from my career in a variety of startups and academia. I've enjoyed being a part of extremely effective small to medium sized teams building recommender systems, reading level classifiers, smart IoT technologies, and streaming analytics. In academia, I've taught applied data science and machine learning at Georgetown University and completed a PhD at the University of Maryland where I studied planetary-scale data systems.   To build great software, you need a great team and as a result, I think knowledge sharing and openness is another critical pillar of my career. I've contributed to many open source projects and am the maintainer of the Yellowbrick Python package - a visual diagnostics tool for machine learning that is affiliated with NumFOCUS. I've presented work at conferences including PyCon and PyData. And finally, I am also an author of two O'Reilly books: Applied Text Analysis with Python and Data Analytics with Hadoop.
Organization Location 1: Washington, District of Columbia, United States
Organization Description 2: Lecturer for the Data Analytics certificate at the Georgetown Center for Continuing Education and Professional Studies. Organization Description 3: Building a PredictiveGrid data platform for the analysis and querying of high-velocity sensor systems. Organization Description 4: My professional career has been one of startups, large and small. Being in a startup is hard, it requires commitment, dedication, and a little bit of self-sacrifice. But the entrepreneurial spirit of taking risks to do something big, often makes those difficulties worth it. Although the fixtures are changed, pursuing a PhD requires that same entrepreneurial character, a willingness to be a jack-of-all-trades, to do what needs to be done if only to make a small contribution to human knowledge. I believe that the disruptive influence of startup culture, combined with my varied academic background has made me able to think and see new opportunities, integrations, and cross-disciplinary approaches that I have brought to my research at the University of Maryland.  Now at last I‚Äôm approaching the final stretch of my academic career. I have completed the course requirements at the University of Maryland and am preparing for my proposal and oral exam. I have also started a research assistantship to study distributed file systems, particularly consistency in user-oriented small scale networks (like the ones between your phone and laptop). I am hoping to create a distributed file system that allows for permanent data that follows you and your devices, and which cannot be corrupted or mangled. see less

Title: Principal Data Scientist at Oracle, former Amazonian, Speaker
Summary: A modern polymath, John possesses a unique and diverse set of skills, knowledge and experience. Having earned advanced degrees in Mechanical Engineering, Kinesiology and Data Science, his expertise focuses on machine learning, solutions to novel and ambiguous problems. He has a proven history of taking a problem from ideation to production by using a logical, but creative, data-driven approach. As a highly skilled Data Scientist, he has developed new techniques, lead teams, developing innovative data products and is a trusted advisor to decision-makers.  John is a natural leader, customer-focused, excellent communicator and problem-solver. He loves new challenges and opportunities. His extensive background in software development and modelling serves him well. His curiosity, creativity, focus and attention to detail have resulted in a track record of discovering hidden secrets in data.  As a Sr. Applied Data Scientist at Amazon, John lead the Alexa Skill Store Science team. He worked closely with engineering to build systems that enabled Alexa customers to engage with third-party applications, skills. He built machine learning models to arbitrate between skills, entity resolution, search, and personalization.  Currently, John is a Principal Data Scientist at Oracle. He works on the Data Science service as part of the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure team. Leveraging his extensive hands-on experience building machine learning models, he is now defining the tooling to improve the data science workflow. This interest grew out of the challenges that he and his team members have faced working with data at scale in a logical, rigorous and reproducible way.  John fosters the growth of scientists by starting the Amazon Machine Learning University in Irvine and the Alexa wide Data Science Excellence program. He frequently gives talks at universities and conferences. He is working to improve upon and formalize data science best practices. The focus has been on reproducible research. To that end, he has developed an approach to improve data validation and reliability by using data unit tests. He has also developed the Data Science Design Thinking concept; to formalize and increase the efficiency of the analysis process. He also coordinates the largest R meetup group in Southern California (OCRUG).

Title: Principal Data Scientist (Kaggle Rank #333)
Summary: I lead the development and deployment of machine learning models and pipelines, with expertise in both real-time and big data architecture, specializing in Apache Spark. My initiatives have generated millions of dollars in revenue and savings for our clients.
Organization Description 1: Design, develop, and deploy scaleable machine learning models for Fortune 500 companies, especially in Deep Learning and AI. Expert in ML frameworks and pipelines for cloud and cluster. Finance, Retail, Automotive, and CPG experience.  Created a SARIMAX model to reduce unplanned absences at FCA manufacturing ‚Ä®plants, using innovative weather, payroll, and event features for forecasts. Implemented many other challenger models such as gradient boosting at the crew and production line level, a base classifier for employee probabilities, and an auto-encoder for anomaly detection to identify outliers using mean squared error. Designed a stacked ensemble for combining models at different levels to improve performance.  Developed a production loss model with non-parametric Monte Carlo Simulation ‚Ä®and a parametric negative binomial distribution (fitdistrplus). This simulation was used to estimate lost production units at manufacturing plants, in contrast to a traditional ARIMA time series model.  Led our Data Science team with presentations on Shapley Additive Explanations for model interpretation; Long Short Term Memory (LSTM) Networks; Apache Spark; Model Production Pipelines; and State-Space Time Series  Released open-source software AlphaPy, an AutoML framework written in Python using scikit-learn, pandas, TensorFlow, and XGBoost. The pipeline creates classification and regression models, combines multiple algorithms, and applies recursive feature elimination with cross-validation, grid search, and automatic model selection (blended or best model). AlphaPy also generates visualizations such as ROC curves, variable importance plots, and lift curves. The final model is pickled and can be deployed into the cloud as either a REST service or Flask route. see less
Organization Description 2: Created a greedy algorithm in Apache Spark as an alternative to a single-threaded auction algorithm, achieving a 50X improvement in performance. The algorithm is a traditional optimization problem for distributing a fixed number of offers to millions of customers with multiple constraints. PySpark and RDD API.  Developed and deployed production models for our retail client over the past two years using Apache Spark, Pig, Hive, and Oozie on the Pivotal HD 3.0 platform. Models include customer segmentation and clustering (K-means); propensity scoring (multinomial); churn, renewal, and attrition (libsvm); association and basket analysis (R arules); seasonality (X-13 ARIMA); and offer assignment (dynamic bidding algorithm).  Managed a team of onshore and offshore developers using agile methodologies for biweekly sprints on three-month epics; Executed customer presentations, demonstrations, and retrospectives on a monthly basis. Consulted with business leaders at the director level for strategic architectural planning to manage models at enterprise scale, including distributed logging, monitoring, and a central repository. see less

Title: Data Scientist
Summary: Solving puzzles to help others, could there be a better job?   I've always loved puzzles and for me the puzzle pieces are data. I love collecting the data, sorting through and connecting the data, and finally using that data to solve a problem and make an impact. Data science has given me the framework to pragmatically apply my math and science skills to puzzles in a wide range of fields. Whether it's marketing models or semi-conductor research, there is data and there is the potential to use that data for overcoming obstacles.   It‚Äôs always been about the data. In the past I‚Äôve worked as a scientist and engineer to solve problems mostly at the lab bench, but the experiments and solutions have always been driven by data. I used data to define the problem, form a hypothesis, and design the experiments. Then the data collected from the experiments was used to build a model, make predictions, and inspire future experiments. While I loved my time in the lab, I've recently decided to apply my efforts towards larger puzzles found in Data Science.

Organization Description 2: Projects: 1. "Evaluating Appointment Postponement in Scheduling Patients at a Diagnostic Clinic." We formulated a Two-stage stochastic integer model to propose the postponement appointment system which decreases the waiting time of higher priority patients in receiving appointments by postponing the acceptance of some lower priority patients.  2. "Dynamic Tuberculosis Test Scheduling for Healthcare Employees." Employees who work in healthcare facilities have to do one of the Tuberculosis (TB) tests mostly every year. We formulated a Markov Decision Process (MDP) that first decides which type of the TB test each employee type has to take based on the characteristics of the group. The model also determines the efficient time between the tests for each employee type because sometimes doing the test every year is not efficient. The goal is to minimize the total cost of the hospital and meanwhile minimize the TB infection rate of each employee type. We applied Approximate Dynamic Programming (ADP) approaches to estimate the MDP solutions. see less

Title: Data Scientist - Team Lead
Summary: I love delving deep into data to uncover insights hidden by noise through end-to-end data science pipelines: architecting, testing and productionizing statistical data analysis to inform good decisions. My fortes include strategic data reduction and featurization, explainable machine learning, and result validation. I also emphasize a collaborative culture and concise but powerful storytelling.  Currently, I lead a team of 5 data physicists studying nuclear physics phenomena in ultrarelativistic collisions at the Large Hadron Collider. We‚Äôve made the first ever measurement of a rare particle family in proton-nucleus collisions, providing unique constraints on the theory of the strong force.  My team and I analyze several terabytes of sensor event data, and simulate collision events using Monte Carlo to augment data and test analysis codebases. Each event contains thousands of particles and there are many millions of events: we identify a 1 in 100, 000 particle signal.
Organization Description 1: I architect end-to-end data science solutions to determine the prevalence of rare particles in particle and nuclear collisions at extremely high energies. Principal analyzer on three and team lead for current project.  To uncover such rare signals in massive CERN data (see needle in a haystack link), I leverage: ‚óÜ Precise ETL pipelining of streaming data. ‚óÜ Data reduction through feature engineering while maximizing signal-to-noise ratio. ‚óÜ Building and constraining explainable ML models based on relationships in data. ‚óÜ Crossvalidating outcomes and correcting for signal loss due to known factors.  Working group: CMS Collaboration, Heavy-Ion group.   More about CERN collisions and my particle of interest: My team and I study proton-proton, proton-lead and lead-lead collisions, all at the same normalized energy. The temperature in these collisions are 5 orders of magnitude hotter than the core of the sun! The colliding particles completely break apart and the large amount of energy gets converted to new particles, including fundamental ones (quarks and gluons) as well as extremely heavy ones that are no longer around today but were produced in the big bang.  We look for the Upsilon (Y) particle. These particles are sensitive to the differences in the three collision types. Lead-lead collisions create the quark-gluon plasma, a new phase of matter. Proton-lead collisions display nuclear effects. Proton-proton collisions provide the baseline for what happens in the absence of nuclear and plasma effects. So by measuring Upsilon particles in all three collisions we can quantify nuclear and plasma effects in nature. see less

Summary: I'm a mechanical engineer who's somehow found his way to data science! Currently working as a Data Scientist at High Peak Software Pvt. Ltd., Bengaluru.  I have expertise in: Python3, C, scikit-learn, pandas, numpy, matplotlib, skimage, opencv, PySpark, Keras, machine learning and deep learning concepts. I am working on projects involving binary and multi-class classification, forecasting and image recognition. Also working towards facial recognition using convolutional neural networks. Familiar with both ML and DL concepts. Prefer to use Python and associated libraries. Use PySpark when the need arises.  Have 54 months of research experience at The Indian Institute of Science, Bengaluru, during which I worked on computational fluid dynamics (CFD) applied to the ironmaking blast furnace. Published one journal paper and one conference paper on novel experimental work done on moving beds. Have 39 months of on-site work experience at The Tata Power Company Ltd., Trombay Thermal Power Station. Worked as an Executive Engineer with the Coal Logistics and Plant Department and supervised the installation, commissioning and maintenance of critical material handling equipments.
Organization Description 2: 1. Binary classification: the target is either 0 or 1. I use the pandas, numpy and scikit-learn libraries from Python to read, clean and encode the dataset. Once the data is prepared, I use the machine learning algorithms from scikit-learn to fit a model to the data. The performance of the trained model gives me clues as to which features are important, whether any new features can be engineered, or whether any algorithm parameters can be changed to improve the performance of the model. With the current project data being imbalanced and the client emphasizing on precision, I focus more on feature engineering and data balancing. I implemented a new method to select lesser number of zeros from the original dataset, and this gave better performance as compared to Undersampling or SMOTE methods. 2. Image Recognition: I have implemented an image recognition program using Python and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) in Keras to identify whether a document belongs to any one of five classes. The documents are scanned PDFs and extracting text using OCR (Optical Character Recognition) is time consuming. Currently, I am able to achieve a 70% accuracy over the five classes. 3. Forecasting and Prediction: I am currently working on an office ergonomics project. I use past data to forecast the user behavior and predict whether the user is at risk of suffering from any pains/injuries due to work. I use Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks for the forecasting and regression for predicting the risk score. see less

Title: Founder and CEO @ Alectio, Machine Learning Entrepreneur
Summary: Who am I? ========= I am a Data Science Leader and a Data Strategist, and I take great pleasure in envisioning the future of Data Science and evangelizing it. I am particularly skilled in growing and managing early-stage data teams, and I am highly comfortable managing hybrid teams, including product managers, data scientists, data analysts and engineers across the board (Front-End, Backend, Systems, etc.)  I am a keynote speaker and have spoken at most major conferences in the field. I like to evangelize not only the role of Data Science in the Industry, but also the key role that women have to play in Tech. I am proud to say that I have inspired many young women to start a career in STEM. I am also a sought-after consultant and have advised countless companies on how to establish a winning data strategy, and how to avoid the common pitfalls when building a data function. I am able to instill a data-centric mindset in even the most skeptical environments.  As a people manager, I believe first and foremost that the best leaders should remain hands-on in order to be able to jump in when needed, and to fully understand the challenges of their team members. I strongly oppose micro-management and believe in empowerment through trust and partnership. I value complete transparency, and I am not scared to say aloud what others keep to themselves.  Finally, if you believe a Data Scientist is meant to run SQL queries or make pie charts all day, then you probably shouldn't contact me :-)  Please find below a sample of my work ================================
Organization Description 1: Building technology to help companies do Machine Learning more efficiently, in particular with less data. By using our platform, ML teams can save an average of 70% on their data preparation and processing costs while getting a significant performance boost. Alectio is also on a mission to help the world do Machine Learning more sustainably by reducing the industry's carbon footprint.  Check us out today: http://www.alectio.com
Organization Description 2: - I help analytics leaders and executives from top companies across the world answer their pressing questions. - I advise them on topics related to data strategy, best practices and technical subjects related to Machine Learning, Deep Learning, Data Quality and Data Engineering. - I offer solutions to evangelize Data Science and Analytics to the C-suite and to build data-driven environments. see less
Organization Description 4: Making AI function in the context of the real world.

Organization Title 6: Sr. Data Science Manager & Principal Data Scientist
Organization Description 6: Managerial experience:  As a member of the Search team, I managed two teams:  - the Metrics-Measurements-Insights team, a group of 9 people (including product managers, engineers and data scientists), in charge of advancing the usage of data and ML best practices within Search. This team also included our Human Evaluation team in charge of preparing training data for the rest of the department. - the Store-Search team, a cross-geo virtual team of 5 data scientists from both Walmart stores and Walmart eCommerce, the very first initiative at Walmart aiming at democratizing the usage of data from Walmart Stores to improve the algorithms used on Walmart.com  Team projects:  - Metrics development: our team developed key metrics for the organization, such as item findability, customer satisfaction, diversity and perception indexes, using both advanced analytics strategies and ML. - Machine Learning Lifecycle Management / Automated Model Management: the team developed tools to enforce and automate ML best practices and manage models without the need for human intervention and accounting for systems performance and cost. - Browse Ranking: the team's new solution increased the revenue coming from browsing customers by ~10%. - Human and Computer Evaluation: our team created active learning algorithms that cut in two the volume of data that the Search Department originally had to be evaluated manually. - Stores-Search: the team developed multiple signals and indicators based on Walmart Stores data to improved the accuracy of the company's Learning-to-Rank models.  Personal projects:  - Review Analysis: I invented an advanced strategy using Post-Purchase Customer Feedback to advise customer purchases (3 patents covering the technology). - Various projects to advice the Data Strategy of the Department and guide Product Development.  Keywords: Predictive Modeling, Reinforcement Learning, Search, NLP, Metrics, Insights, Analytics see less

An automated R pipeline does it all quickly and is scalable, reproducible, sustainable, and debuggable. Reduced analysts' work by about 90%, taking it from ~20 hrs per monthly iteration, to 2 hrs.  - Engaging in various NLP initiatives with a vision to promote NLP capabilities in the institution for the sake of extracting valuable clinical-oncological information which is otherwise "trapped" in medical records and reports. This passion led me to join hands with the Radiology department in a novel and exciting NLP project, employing 400K radiology reports of cancer patients (representing 30 different cancers and 12 different body organs), and developing NLP algorithms around it, looking to serve the institution's operations (by understanding each patient's disease status), and the oncology community (by sharing the progression of 30 different cancer diseases as they metastesize across the different organs).  - Engage in professional development programs  Additional concrete impact he has made: Cutting down time and labor through automating analytics pipelines, Reducing patient overflow by providing a forecast of patient census, Automating EHR annotation through a novel webapp that saves time, labor, and mistakes. see less

Organization Title 3: Sr. Predictive Modeling Engineer, Algorithms Team
Organization Description 3: Following our success we started expanding the algorithms team. I took over a senior role, orienting the newcomers from the aspect of our algorithms and development. Each of them took on new development tasks, such as developing our interface of making model choices, or designing methodologies around experiments that feedback to our algorithmic development.  I remained the key algorithmic developer. I enhanced our model validation scheme and developed a novel approach to a tough problem that we were trying to solve and that would be groundbreaking in one of the largest consumer markets.  With time I started also engaging with clients and consulting in meetings of product and business development, advising on solution feasibility, trade-offs, estimated timelines, resources, etc. I later took on my first project, working with the client's R&D team to putting together a solution to their need.  I found the contribution to product development and business development to be very empowering, as it allows people from both sides to put together a collaboration that suits both organizations. Nevertheless, my strongest affection was to the algorithmic development.  I left Silentium late 2014 as I moved to NYC and was looking for a local role. see less
Organization Description 4: Silentium is a ground-breaking tech startup in ANC (Active Noise Control).  In late 2010 Silentium completed a research collaboration with academia with a purpose of achieving a theoretical proof of concept for advancing its technology. Next move was to start developing the mathematical and computational algorithms to achieve what was proven conceptually feasible. I was the first developer brought on board for that purpose. I was fresh out of school but had a strong toolset, unbiased thinking, with a boost of creativity and motivation to do something new. I was tasked with the first algorithmic milestone and given an unlimited amount of time to solve it. It took me less than a week to develop it, implement in code, and validate. It was and remains one of the sweetest moments of my career.  Next we applied it in a physical setting and found that the calculations and the validation in code were correct. We had created a set of quiet spots around a person's head using multiple speakers (while previous existing algorithms only allowed for a single speaker, thus making the quiet spots not as quiet).  Interest from prospective clients started growing and more business came in.  I continued refining our algorithmic toolbag and in the following year I expended the initial algorithm to take-in data from multiple microphones (previous existing algorithms allowed for only a single microphone, thus not accommodating for various noise scattering). This development became known as the Silentium Quiet-Bubble‚Ñ¢.  Algorithmic aspects: - Language: Matlab - Developing solutions: Bayesian statistics for putting together the equations to be optimized, Spectral analysis for supplying the physical constraints of the hardware (speakers in particular), Convex optimization and parameter estimation for setting up a solution to the equations, - Model validation: Train, validation, and test sets. - Code integrity: Putting together tests that validate the output of the algorithm. see less
Education Description 1: Master thesis-dissertation under the supervision of Prof. Hagit Messer-Yaron, see details in the publications section. As cellular providers constantly monitor signal power for operational needs, a novel approach suggests utilizing this data for deriving the weather. My research dealt with defining mathematical criteria for when the given data is sufficient to allow for reconstruction of the precipitation map, and to what precision. I developed a mathematical analysis and modeling based on Compressed-Sensing theory, dealing with underdetermined systems of linear-equations. My research was successful, published in IEEE, and rose interest from several institutions to offer a Phd program, but my intention is to make my contribution out in the industry.Technical aspects:‚Ä¢ Coding and simulations‚Ä¢ Sparse observations and modeling‚Ä¢ l1 / regularized regression‚Ä¢ Image modeling and linear transformations

Title: Data & Technology Consultant
Summary: Having earned an Applied Math & Economics Bachelors degree from Harvard, and a Masters in Data Science from Columbia, I enjoy bridging the quantitative and the qualitative worlds together, using technology and data science to translate numbers into real-life applications, to influence strategy, business practices and decision making in both the private sector and the public sphere. That's why I founded Datavima.   At Datavima, our goal is to leverage technology, in the form of Data Analysis (simple or sophisticated Machine Learning algorithms, as needed) and/or Product and Application Development to help clients generate insights from data, and improve the day-to-day management of their businesses and their bottom-line.   At PlaceIQ we focused on location intelligence. I developed algorithms for the ingestion of data (location-based and otherwise) from multiple sources into our Platform, as well as its processing and analysis, including Audience Scoring and Dwell Prediction.   At Oliver Wyman Labs, I continued to straddle the business and tech worlds, as a "consultant + developer." As a consultant, I interacted with clients to understand their problems and develop solutions, as well as managed the projects and client relationships. On the tech side, I was also responsible for guiding the development and often programming myself data science/machine learning solutions to clients' problems, as well as building out web tools, and at times, both.   After finishing my Masters in Data Science at Columbia I decided to dedicate myself to Datavima.

Organization Description 3: At Clickfox, in the role of Data Scientist I contributed to project design, analytic modeling, and presentations for client engagements. I Used CART and ensemble methods, boosting and bagging, to build prediction and description models, with time series event data. I contributed research and prototyping analytic algorithms for Clickfox (CEA) product features. I developed numerous analytic tools in R and python.  The most recent project, for a major US bank, predicted silent attrition and attrition. I was the team lead on the project, and was responsible for data mining, data quality evaluation, data engineering, and building and evaluating mathematical models. For this project, I chose to use a decision tree for numerous reasons, most importantly the data was not fully populated, it contained categorical variables, and varying numeric scales.  My team and I researched text mining methods, most successfully a variation of Term Frequency times Inverse Document Frequency (tf*idf), for anomaly detection on event data sets. The goal was to value to the data by assigning customer experience scores. This was very successful and a lot of fun. We planned to introduce a new measurement, similar to NPS and CSAT, to be able to score the entire customer population! We built this in python, using mercurial for source control.  Another area of research was random forest prediction accuracy vs time, number of trees, and bootstrap sample size. I wrote a function in R to present the data as an updating graph, to show the changes in time and accuracy, as the sample size increased and number of trees increased. This exercise determined the fastest way to build the forest with minimal loss in performance. see less

Education Description 2: The pricing effect of large speculators and price run-ups in the New York Mercantile Exchange (NYMEX) crude oil futures market.My topic relates to whether crude oil futures trading by non-commercial firms ("speculators") causes price run-ups or is the result of market manipulation. Previous studies suggest that the activity of market speculators has driven up the price of crude oil (Davidson, 2008; Engdahl, 2008; Kaufmann & Ullman, 2009; Smith, 2009).The research design is a multivariate time series that tests hypotheses whether open interest (the quantity of undelivered futures contracts) and price are cointegrated. Once the cointegration (or lack) is established, the research will determine which events precedes the other: change in open interest, or price. If, for example, a rising open interest is occurring slightly before a price run-up, there may be reason to believe that crude oil futures manipulation is occurring.
